peace, whether they occur in the streets o:

Sec. 14. A police officer must be cautious
never to interfere idly or unnecessarily ; but when
required to act he will do so with discretion, decision and boldness; and he may arrest any one
who may oppose him in the execution of his duty,
if he can prove any specific act, but not otherwise.
Sec. 15. A police officer is not authorized to
assist in arresting without a warrant, a party
charged with disorderly conduct, or an assault, or
similar offence, not committed in his presence; nor
should he receive into his custody a person s
charged, unless the party has been arrested by a
person who saw the offence committed.
VAGRANTS.
Sec. 16. It is the duty of every Police 0:
or Policeman to arrest and convey before the Recorders of their respective districts, or to the Po?
lice? Station House, as the case may be, habitual
drunkards who are destitute and without visible j
means of support; common prostitutes who have j
